p: Seizures are common in viral encephalitis and are often subtle, but intractable [ 7]. Such cases may evolve into status epilepticus and even non-convulsive status epilepticus [ 10]. If a patient presents with a new-onset status epilepticus a viral cause should be considered [ 7]. Patients with viral encephalitis may have electroclinical dissociation, so that motor activity during the seizure is not visible, and can be detected only with an EEG [ 10]. Other subtle clinical signs of seizures are a bitten tongue, injuries, and twitching of an eyelid or corner of the mouth [ 10]. Failure to control the seizures inevitably increases the metabolic activity, resulting in acidosis with vasodilation and increased ICP [ 13].
